biblStruct.note: received March 23, 2015; revised December 12, 2015; accepted December 20, 2015.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This paper is concerned with the problem of extended dissipativity-based state estimation for discrete-time Markov jump neural networks (NNs), where the variation of the piecewise time-varying transition probabilities of Markov chain is subject to a set of switching signals satisfying an average dwell-time property. The communication links between the NNs and the estimator are assumed to be imperfect, where the phenomena of signal quantization and data packet dropouts occur simultaneously. The aim of this paper is to contribute with a Markov switching estimator design method, which ensures that the resulting error system is extended stochastically dissipative, in the simultaneous presences of packet dropouts and signal quantization stemmed from unreliable communication links. Sufficient conditions for the solvability of such a problem are established. Based on the derived conditions, an explicit expression of the desired Markov switching estimator is presented. Finally, two illustrated examples are given to show the effectiveness of the proposed design method.

are still quite intriguing from both the theoretical and practical points of view [4]. Thereinto, one of these issues is the information latching problem of recurrent NNs (RNNs) [5], [6]. A popular and available way to cope with such a problem is to extract finite-state representations (namely, clusters, patterns, and modes) from the trained networks [7], [8]. In this case, the considered RNNs have finite modes, which can jump or switch from one to another at different instants of time [7], [9]- [12]. For this reason, there has been a considerable interest in the study of Markov jump NNs (MJNNs) based on the original work of [13]. So far, some important advances on MJNNs have been presented, for instance [7], [8], [14]- [17], and the references therein.

However, such existing literature commonly has one principal drawback, i.e., the states of NNs were assumed to be completely known. Moreover, in order to achieve design specifications in many practical applications of NNs, one often is required to provide the information on the states of NNs. It is sometimes a difficult task. The more practical scenario is that we have to face the unmeasurable states of NNs, or only partial available information from the network outputs in practice. To deal with such an issue, a fundamental problem in the control theory, called state estimation, has been proposed in the study of NNs [18]- [21]. Specifically, the problem is to estimate the neuron states with the aid of available output measurements, such that the resulting error system is stable. Due to its theoretical and practical importance, such a problem has been investigated by many researchers in a number of contexts. For instance, considering the external disturbance, the conditions have been presented in many existing works under which the desired estimators can be designed. To name a few, the H ∞ state estimator design method was developed in [22]; the passivity-based state estimation problem was solved in [23]. Noticing that the dissipativity theory generalizes some basic theories, such as H ∞ theory, passivity theory, and positive real theory [24]- [26], and Wang et al. [27] consider the dissipativity-based state estimation problem of NNs. Unfortunately, the results failed to deal with the state estimator design problem in L 2 -L ∞ /l 2l ∞ sense. How to overcome this shortcoming, therefore, is still an opening issue for researchers up to now.

On the other hand, the rapid development of the network and communication technologies provides a commodious way to analyze and design large distributed plants [28]- [31]. In this regard, it is not difficult to understand that networked control systems (NCSs) have attracted a great deal of attention among researchers from different disciplines [32], [33]. The NCSs consist of many sensors, controllers/estimators, and actuators, which are connected through a shared communication network. Major advantages of NCSs range from the reduced power requirements, low cost, to simple installation and maintenance. Hence, it is necessary to study the state estimation problem for NNs in the NCSs framework. However, an inevitable problem is the existence of many networkinduced phenomena, occurring on the communication channel. As reported in [10] and [34]- [37], these phenomena, such as packet dropouts, signal quantization, actuator/sensor saturation, random communication time delays, and so forth, could degrade the performance of NCSs significantly. In most of the existing literature about the analysis and synthesis problems for NNs in the NCSs framework, only communication time delays were considered [38]. The other intriguing question arises naturally: how to investigate the dissipativity-based state estimation problem of NNs subject to other types of network-induced phenomena, in particular packet dropouts and signal quantization simultaneously? Although its importance has been recognized, little attention has been paid to this issue, which, of course, further motivates our work.

Inspired by the above observations, in this paper, we address the extended dissipative state estimation problem for a class of MJNNs, where the transition probabilities (TPs) of Markov chain are piecewise time-varying. The system measurements are transmitted over a lossy network, which leads to the simultaneous occurrences of packet dropouts and signal quantization. Attention is focused on the design of a state estimator, such that the resulting error system is extended dissipative. Based on some stochastic analysis techniques, the sufficient conditions are established for the solvability of the addressed problem. The desired state estimator is constructed by solving a convex optimization problem. Two illustrative examples finally are provided to show the effectiveness of the developed method. The main contributions of this paper are listed as follows.
1) The system model addressed is comprehensive.

In [8], [18], [19], and [27], the TPs of Markov chain are assumed to be completely known. However, this assumption may sometimes be invalid in practice, such as NCSs with packet dropouts and biochemical systems with diverse changes. In order to overcome the shortcoming of this assumption, we introduce the Markov chain with the piecewise time-varying TPs to govern the switching between the modes, which has wider applications than those in [8], [18], [19], and [27].

In addition, the variation of the piecewise time-varying TPs is subject to a set of switching signals based on the concept of average dwell time (ADT). 2) Different from the addressed dissipative state estimation problem in [24] and [27], we employ an extended dissipative inequality [see (17)], and make the first attempt to cope with the l 2l ∞ and dissipativity-based state estimation problems for MJNNs subject to unreliable communication links in a unified way. 3) By using the stochastic analysis theory and introducing some slack variables, the problem to be solved can be converted into a convex optimization problem without applying the complex cone complementarity linearization (CCL) procedure. As a consequence, the desired state estimator can be readily constructed. Notations: Throughout this paper, the notations used are fairly standard. R n denotes the n-dimensional Euclidean space. Z + is used to denote the set of nonnegative integers. For symmetric matrices X and Y, the notation X ≥ Y (respectively, X > Y ) means that the matrix X -Y is positive semidefinite (respectively, positive definite); I is the identity matrix with appropriate dimensions. The notation M T represents the transpose of the matrix M. In symmetric block matrices or complex matrix expressions, we employ an asterisk ( * ) to represent a term that can be induced by symmetry and diag{. . .} stands for a block diagonal matrix; E {•} denotes the expectation operator with respect to some probability measure P; Pr{A} means the occurrence probability of the event A; l 2 [0, ∞) is the space of square-integrable vector functions over [0, ∞); |•| refers to the Euclidean vector norm; • 2 stands for the usual l 2 [0, ∞) norm. Matrices, if not explicitly stated, are assumed to have compatible dimensions.

In this paper, we suppose that the measurement output y(k) of system ( ) is represented as follows:
div.formula: y(k) = B(λ k )x(k) + F(λ k )ω(k)(5)
div.p: where B(λ k ) and F(λ k ) are known constant matrices for each λ k . Taking the signal quantization into account, we assume that the signals are quantized by the logarithmic quantizer before entering into the desired estimator, where
As discussed in [39], the set of the logarithmic quantization levels for each
div.formula: Q h [ ](1 ≤ h ≤ n) is described by U h = ± u (h) l , u (h) l = ρ (l) h u (h) 0 , l = 0, ±1, ±2, . . . ∪ {0}(6)
div.p: with the quantization density ρ h ∈ [0, 1] and u (h) 0 > 0. Each quantization level corresponds to a segment of the input of quantizer, such that the quantizer maps the whole segment to this quantization level. For the logarithmic quantizer, Q h [ h ] is defined as follows:
div.formula: Q h [ h ] = ⎧ ⎪ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎪ ⎩ u (h) l , 1 1 + δ h u (h) l < h ≤ 1 1 -δ h u (h) l 0, h = 0 -Q h (-h ), h ≤ 0 (7) with δ h (1 -ρ h /1 + ρ h ).
div.p: Inspired by [34], it is not difficult to deduce that
div.formula: Q h [ h ] = (1 + h ) h (8) such that | h | ≤ δ h for each h ∈ [1, n].
div.p: For notational simplicity, we use y pq (k) and Q[y pq (k)] to denote the actual input available to the quantizer and the corresponding actual input of the desired estimator, respectively. Under the assumption that the communication network link between the physical plant and the quantizer is perfect, it is easy to find that y(k) = y pq (k). However, as one of the common network-induced imperfections, the phenomenon of data packet dropouts inevitably occurs in practice. That is, the measurements y(k) drop intermittently, which means that y(k) = y pq (k). For this reason, we model the data packet dropouts phenomenon by using a stochastic Bernoulli approach, which has been verified to be effective [40]. Thus, the connection between y(k) and y pq (k) is shown as follows:
div.formula: y pq (k) = β k y(k) (9)
div.p: where the stochastic variable β k is a Bernoulli-distributed white noise sequence specified by the following distribution law [40]:
div.formula: Pr{β k = 1} = E{β k } = β, Pr{β k = 0} = 1 - β where β ∈ [0, 1] is a known constant.
div.p: Clearly, the communication link is in complete failure when β = 0, and the communication link is in normal case when β = 1. For the stochastic variable β k , it is also easy to see
In this paper, denoting diag{ 1 , 2 , . . . , n }, we are interested in designing the following state estimator ( ˆ ) :

div.p: Before describing the objective of this paper, we first introduce the following definitions, which will be indispensable for the derivations of our main results.
Definition 1 [41]: For switching signal σ and any
div.formula: K ≥ k ≥ k 0 , let N σ (K, k) be the switching number of σ over the interval [k, K). If we have N σ (K, k) ≤ N 0 + K -k τ a
div.p: holds for any fixed N 0 > 0 and τ a > 0, then τ a is called the ADT and N 0 is called the chatter bound. Definition 2 [12]: System ( ˜ ) with ω (k) ≡ 0 is said to be mean-square stochastically stable if for k ≥ 0 and each initial condition ζ(0) and λ 0 , the following condition holds:
Definition 3 [26]: For given real matrices
div.formula: Q 1 = Q T 1 ≤ 0, Q 2 , Q 3 = Q T 3 > 0, and Q 4 = Q T 4 ≥ 0 satisfying ( Q 1 + Q 2 ) • Q 4 = 0, system(
div.p: ˜ ) is said to be extended stochastically dissipative, if for any ω(k) ∈ l 2 [0, ∞), the following inequality is satisfied under zero initial condition:

where k) is denoted by the energy supply f uncti on for system ( ˜ ). Definition 3 is borrowed and improved from these existing ones of discrete-time systems. As stated in [24] and [27], the dissipative problem is more general than many other typical control issues, which includes H ∞ control, positive real control, sector bounded control, and passivity-based control, to name just a few. Hence, the dissipativity theorem provides an opportunity to solve such control issues in a unified framework.
div.formula: J(Q 1 , Q 2 , Q 3 , k) zT (k)Q 1 z(k) + 2z T (k)Q 2 ω(k) + ω T (k)Q 3 ω(k). Remark 1: Normally, the function T k=0 J(Q 1 , Q 2 , Q 3 ,
div.p: Remark 2: It is known that there are many results on the state estimation of MJNNs, for example, [14], [18], [19], [26], and the references therein. In comparison with the existing results, the system model investigated in the paper is comprehensive, where the TPs of Markov chain are piecewise time-varying. Moreover, different from the addressed dissipative state estimation problem in [24] and [27], we will investigate such a problem based on Definition 3, namely, extended stochastic dissipativity. The main advantage of our developed approach is that one can solve not only the normal dissipativity-based state estimation problem but also the state estimation problem in l 2l ∞ sense by tuning some weighting matrices, and therefore, the convenience is brought to the researchers. In addition, the network-induced phenomena, especially signal quantization and data packet dropouts, have been fully considered in this paper.
Then, the problems concerned in this paper are formulated as follows.
Problem I (Extended Stochastic Dissipativity Analysis): For given estimator parameters K i (i ∈ S) and real matrices
div.formula: Q 1 = Q T 1 ≤ 0, Q 2 , Q 3 = Q T 3 > 0, and Q 4 = Q T 4 ≥ 0 satisfying ( Q 1 + Q 2 ) • Q 4 = 0, determine the condition under which system ( ˜ ) is extended stochastically dissipative.
div.p: Problem II (Extended Stochastically Dissipative State Estimation): For given real matrices
div.formula: Q 1 = Q T 1 ≤ 0, Q 2 , Q 3 = Q T 3 > 0, and Q 4 = Q T 4 ≥ 0 satisfying ( Q 1 + Q 2 ) • Q 4 = 0,
div.p: design a dissipativity-based state estimator in the form of ( 11) and ( 12) (i.e., determining the estimator parameters K i ) such that system ( ˜ ) is extended stochastically dissipative.

div.head: A. Extended Stochastic Dissipativity Analysis
div.p: In this section, we first study the dissipativity analysis for system ( ˜ ). The following theorem will provide a sufficient condition, such that system ( ˜ ) is extended stochastically dissipative in the sense of Definition 3. Furthermore, based on the proposed condition, a state estimator design method will be presented in Section III-B.
Theorem 1: Suppose that

div.p: Furthermore, under zero initial conditions, we will establish the extended stochastic dissipativity condition for any nonzero ω(k) ∈ l 2 [0, ∞), that is, the condition in ( 17) is satisfied. By Definition 3, it should be pointed out that the extended dissipativity condition can represent the strict dissipativity condition and l 2l ∞ performance criterion by tuning an appropriate matrix Q 4 as Q 4 > 0 or Q 4 = 0. Therefore, in what follows, we will consider two cases (Q 4 > 0 and

div.p: Therefore, condition ( 17) is satisfied under Cases 1 and 2, which implies that system ( ˜ ) is extended stochastically dissipative by Definition 3.

Remark 3: In this paper, the estimation error appearing in the elements of TPM will bring difficulties in the following state estimator design. We set that G is a given convex bound polyhedral domain described by vertices

div.head: B. Extended Stochastically Dissipative State Estimator Design
div.p: In the following, we focus on designing a state estimator in the form of ( 11) and ( 12) based on Theorem 1, namely, to determine estimator parameters K i in (11) and (12).
The following theorem gives a sufficient condition to ensure the existence of the desired state estimator in (11) and (12).
Theorem 2: Consider system ( ˜ ), and given real matrices

Therefore, by following a similar line as that in the proof of Theorem 1, one can obtain that system ( ˜ ) is extended stochastically dissipative. This completes the proof.
By means of Theorem 2, we decide to perform the extended dissipative state estimator design algorithm as follows.
Step 1: Choose some values for matrices - μ, α, andβ.
div.formula: 2 , + 2 , J i , Q 1 , Q 2 , and Q 4 satisfying ( Q 1 + Q 2 ) • Q 4 = 0; scalars ρ(h),
div.p: Step 2: Set an initial value for Q 3 .

Step 3: For system ( ˜ ), find a solution to the specific LMIs feasibility problem in Theorem 2. Due to Q 3 > 0, without loss of generality, initializing Q 3 = ιI , ι = 1, we keep decreasing ι until a solution can be obtained.
Step 4: If no solution is found, then the initial value for Q 3 should be increased, and go to Step 3, otherwise, EXIT and restart to Step 1 with different values of μ, α,
div.formula: J i , Q 1 , Q 2 , and Q 4 satisfying ( Q 1 + Q 2 ) • Q 4 = 0.

div.p: 1i Y i . Remark 4: It should be remarkable that P (m) i,θ and (P (m) i,θ ) -1 appear simultaneously in the derivation of Theorem 2. In this case, it is difficult to obtain a strict LMIs-based condition. IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON NEURAL NETWORKS AND LEARNING SYSTEMS One possible way to solve such a problem has been well recognized in employing a CCL procedure [42]. It is powerful but brings an increasing computational burden due to its complex iterative algorithm, especially for MJNNs with multimodes. In order to alleviate the heavy computational burden, we here introduce a set of inequalities -G (m)
div.formula: i (P (m) i,θ ) -1 (G (m) i ) T ≤ J i P (m) i,θ J T i -G (m) i J T i -J i (G (m)
div.p: i ) T , and consequently, the application of a CCL procedure can be avoided.

Remark 5: For system ( ), Theorem 2 gives a sufficient condition for the solvability of the dissipativity-based state estimation problem. It should be pointed out that the proposed condition gives a unified framework for the state estimation issue of MJNNs, which can be directly used to deal with the passivity-based or H ∞ state estimation problem. For instance, by following a similar line in the proof of Theorem 2, the following corollary provides a sufficient condition for the solvability of the H ∞ state estimation problem of system ( ).
Corollary 1: Consider system ( ), and given the matrices
div.formula: Q 1 = -I, Q 2 = 0, Q 3 = γ 2 I, Q 4 = 0 and the scalar γ > 0. System ( ˜ ) is stochastically stable with a prescribed H ∞ performance level, if there exist matrices G (m) i diag G 1i , G (m) 2i , P (m) i P (m) 1i P (m) 2i * P (m) 3i > 0, Y i
div.p: such that ( 36) and ( 37) hold for each i ∈ S and m ∈ M. Remark 6: In practical implementation of NNs, the time delays inevitable exist and generally degrade the performance of the designed estimator. In addition, there are some deviations in the parameters of NNs. The reason is that the parameters depend on the resistance and capacitance values, which are subject to uncertainties. It should be remarkable that our proposed state estimation scheme can be extended to deal with the state estimation problem for network-based discretetime MJNNs with time delays and/or parameter uncertainties.

div.head: IV. NUMERICAL EXAMPLES
div.p: In this section, we present two numerical examples to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed state estimation scheme.
Example 1: We consider the following DTMJNNs with two modes.
Mode 1 where
div.formula: f 1 (x 1 (k)) tanh(x 1 (k)) and f 2 (x 2 (k)) = tanh(x 2 (k)).
div.p: It is straightforward to observe that both f 1 (x 1 (k)) and f 2 (x 2 (k)) satisfy Assumption 1, and the matrices -and + can be calculated as -= 0 and + = diag{0.5, 0.5}.

In this example, the parameters of the quantizer Q[•] are selected as u (1) 0 = u (2) 0 = 0.003. We also assume that J 1i = I for i = 1, 2. The TPM (σ k ) is time-varying, which is determined by a high-level ADT switching signal σ k taking its values in a finite set M = {1, 2}. As discussed in Section III, for each σ k , we also assume that (σ k ) cannot be exactly measured but has bounded estimation errors, which are shown as follows:
(2) = 0.4 + e 2 0.6e 2 0.3 + e 2 0.7e 2 (45) with -0.05 ≤ e 1 ≤ 0.05 and -0.1 ≤ e 2 ≤ 0.1. In view of Remark 3, the TPMs in (45) can be represented by the following two-vertex polytopic form:
where

(1) Problem 1 (DSE Problem): In this case, our first aim is to straighten out the relationships among Q 3 , α, and the quantization density ρ 1 and ρ 2 . For this reason, the probability representing the degree of occurring packet dropouts is considered as β = 0.7. In addition, we assign the minimum allowable values of Q 3 ensuring the feasibility of conditions (36) and (37) are calculated for different values of α as listed in Tables I andII.
For the sake of analysis convenience, in light of Tables I andII, the relationships among Q 3 , α, and ρ are further intuitively shown in Fig. 1.

Two noteworthy facts can be observed from Fig. 1. One is that the minimum allowable values of Q 3 monotonously decrease as the quantization density ρ increases. Note that Q 3 can be used to represent the dissipative margin, which means that the increasing quantization density ρ may play a positive role in improving the system performance. Another is that the minimum allowable values of Q 3 increase as the value of α increases for each fixed ρ, which provides a reference on how to select the appropriate value of α.
Furthermore, letting

02, ρ = 0.9, β = 0.7, and Q 4 = 0, and solving the LMIs conditions in Theorem 2, one can get the estimator gains for the considered systems for different values of α. The computation results are listed in Table III.

Problem 2 (l 2l ∞ State Estimation Problem): The objective of such a problem is to design an l 2l ∞ state estimator and find out the admissible switching signals and to guarantee that the considered system is stochastically stable with a prescribed l 2l ∞ performance level. For this purpose, we set that

Then, given different pairs of (μ, α), the minimum allowable values of Q 3 and τ * a ensuring the feasibility of the conditions in Theorem 2 can be obtained, which are presented in Table IV. Furthermore, in order to facilitate observation, we enumerate the minimum allowable values of Q 3 and τ * a for the fixed pairs of (μ, α) more visually, which are shown in Figs. 2 and3, respectively. From Table IV and Figs. 2 and3, we can find that, the selection of (μ, α) can properly determine the minimum allowable values of Q 3 and the lower bound of ADT.
Besides, let gains by solving the LMIs conditions in Theorem 2, which are shown in Table V.

In the simulation, we set the external disturbance input be ω(k) = (0.8/1 + k 2 ), and let the initial conditions be x(0) = [ 0.7 -0.7 ] T and x(0) = [ 0 0 ] T , respectively. Here, we employ the obtained estimator gains (which correspond to the case of α = 0.01 in Table V) system ( ˜ ), and we obtain the response of the estimation error e(k) with a possible modes evolution, as in Fig. 4, which clearly shows that the state estimator design method is effective in the presence of packet dropouts and quantization.

Example 2: In this example, we employ a biological network, namely, the repressilator model, in Escherichia coli to demonstrate the applicability and effectiveness of the proposed method. Inspired by the fundamental work of [3], the repressilator model shown in Fig. 5 can be seen as a synthetic genetic regulatory network.
The kinetics of the model are represented by the following coupled differential equations borrowed from [9]:
div.formula: ṁi = -m i + α i 1 + p n j (48) ṗi = -β i ( p i -m i ) (49
div.p: where p i stands for three repressor-protein concentrations with i = lacl, tet R, cl; m i denote their corresponding mRNA concentrations with j = cl, lacl, tet R; β i represents the ratio of the protein decay rate to the mRNA decay rate; n is a Hill coefficient. As stated in [3], the discrete nature of the molecular components and the stochastic character of their interactions play important roles in biochemical and genetic networks. Considering these effects, we will transform ( 48) and (49) into the following discrete-time model with the stochastic mode switching as studied in [9]:
div.formula: m(k + 1) = C 1λ k m(k) + A 1λ k g( p(k)) (50) p(k + 1) = C 2λ k p(k) + C 3λ k m(k). (51
div.p: Here, p(k) T , where p l (k) and m l (k), respectively, denote the concentrations of protein and mRNA of the lth node at time k; g l ( p l (k)) stands for the feedback regulation on the lth metabolite. The diagonal matrices
div.formula: C 1λ k diag{C 1 1λ k , C 2 1λ k , . . . , C n 1λ k }, C 2λ k diag{C 1 2λ k , C 2 2λ k , . . . , C n 2λ k },
l 2λ k | < 1; A 1λ k (A lk 1λ k )
div.p: is the coupling matrix of the genetic network and A lk 1λ k is defined as follows: A lk 1λ k > 0 if transcription k is an activator of gene l for each mode λ k ; A lk 1λ k = 0 if there is no link from gene k to l for each mode λ k ; A lk 1λ k < 0 if transcription k is a repressor of gene l for each mode λ k . These stochastic switching parameters (C 1λ k , A 1λ k , C 2λ k , and C 3λ k ) are generated from a general Markov chain λ k , as denoted in Section II. For simplicity, we denote C 1λ k C 1i , and the others can be similarly denoted. Then, when the external disturbance is considered, (50) and (51) may be represented as follows:
div.formula: x(k + 1) = C i x(k) + A i g(x(k)) + E i ω(k) (52)
div.p: where
div.formula: x(k) [m T (k) p T (k)] T , g(x(k)) [g T (m(k)) g T ( p(k))] T C i C 1i 0 C 3i C 2i , A i 0 A 1i 0 0 .
div.p: In this example, we assume that model (52) has two modes, and the TPM of the generated Markov chain {λ k } is the same as that in Example 1. The parameters of model ( 52) and the measurement output (5) are borrowed from [9] as follows: In addition, as discussed in [9], we also choose the regulation function as g(s) = s 2 /(1 + s 2 ), which means φ - l = 0 and φ + l = 0.65 for each l. By solving the LMIs conditions in Theorem 2 for the fixed scalars Q 3 = 1, Q 1 = 0, Q 2 = 0, Q 4 = 1, μ = 1.02, ρ = 0.1, β = 0.7, and J lk = I, l, k = 1, 2, the following estimator gains are obtained: In the simulation, the initial values of the system state and the estimator state are x(0) = [0.08 0.17 0.04 1.13 1.87 1.25] T and x(0) = [-0.2 0.1 -0.1 -0.2 0 0.2] T , respectively. The external disturbance input is selected as

. By employing the above given estimator gains to model (52), the error response of the estimation error system is shown in Fig. 6 with the evolutions of system modes. It can be shown that proposed approach can be applied to the study of the biological network (52).

V. CONCLUSION In this paper, the problem of extended dissipative state estimation has been investigated for a class of MJNNs with the double-switching structure. In such a structure, the variation of the piecewise time-varying TPs of Markov chain governing the underlying modes transition of NNs is subject to a set of switching signals satisfying ADT property. Besides, the phenomena of signal quantization and data packet dropouts, occurring simultaneously on the communication links between the NNs and the estimator, have also been considered. Sufficient conditions have been derived to guarantee that the resulting estimation error system is extended stochastically dissipative. In terms of these conditions, the corresponding estimator design problem has been cast into a convex optimization problem, and consequently, the desired Markov switching state estimator can be readily structured by using standard numerical softwares. Finally, two classes of frequently used network models in the discrete-time domain (MJNNs and GRNs, respectively) have been provided to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach. It is noteworthy that how to extend our results to more complex MJNNs, such as semi-Markov jump NNs and delayed MJNNs, in the sliding mode/adaptive control framework is an important direction of our future research, which deserves further exploration.

His current research interests include stochastic hybrid systems, network control systems, nonlinear systems, and their applications. Yanzheng Zhu (S'15) received the B.S. degree in network engineering from the Shandong University of Science and Technology

monogr.title: His current research interests include stochastic switched systems, nondeterministic switched systems, and neural networks
